Sentence: Emma knows nothing about Frank, who has long been deterred from visiting his (Frank) father by his (Frank) aunt's illnesses and complaints
Emma, however, finds Frank delightful and notices that his (Frank) charms are directed mainly toward her (Emma)
Everyone assumes that Frank and Emma are forming an attachment, though Emma soon dismisses Frank as a potential suitor and imagines him (Frank) as a match for Harriet
When Harriet tells Emma that she (Emma) has fallen in love with a man above her (Emma) social station, Emma believes that she (Emma) means Frank
Knightley begins to suspect that Frank and Jane have a secret understanding, and he (Frank) attempts to warn Emma
Emma laughs at Knightley's suggestion and loses Knightley's approval when she (Emma) flirts with Frank and insults Miss Bates, a kindhearted spinster and Jane's aunt, at a picnic
Frank and Jane have been secretly engaged; his (Frank) attentions to Emma have been a screen to hide his (Frank) true preference
Emma worries that Harriet will be crushed, but she (Emma) soon discovers that it is Knightley, not Frank, who is the object of Harriet's affection
